Thanks to all MPs who've called out this government's contempt for working people. Whatever happens next, this is a bad deal for jobs and rights and trade unions will stand against it. The people must have the final say.

The govt's meaningless proposals on workers' rights change nothing. We still have no legally binding guarantee that UK rights will keep pace with EU minimum standards.

Don't be conned. This is a bad deal for working people and MPs should vote against it.
https://t.co/NQDjwwdkxb
As expected, nothing in here to give working people the protection they need. https://t.co/dRZCQHpNLa

Thanks to all MPs who've stood up for working people by standing firm against a devastating no-deal. Boris Johnson is not above the law. He must now secure an extension.

The people must have the final say - it's our jobs, rights and livelihoods that are on the line.

I understand this is a difficult time. But defending working people’s rights is at the heart of everything trade unions believe in. For the sake of working families now and in the future, we can’t support a deal that will trash those rights. We ask MPs to vote against it. 7/

At any point in this Brexit process, govt could have agreed to an internationally binding legal commitment to maintain existing rights and ensure that rights keep pace. At every stage it’s refused to do so. Why would we trust this sudden change of heart? 6/

And as for relying on the Queen’s Speech as evidence that it supports workers’ rights - all the QS contained was vague, ineffectual commitments and woolly promises. The govt said nothing that would change the game for working people (or challenge big business). 5/

Govt suggesting it will consult on unfair dismissal and TUPE (which would already be weakened the morning after we leave the EU) is meaningless – it’s not a commitment to implementing the changes working people need. 4/

They sit alongside the Brexit deal itself, which doesn’t require that UK rights keep pace, and leaves workers with far less power to enforce rights they do have. These half-baked domestic proposals are no match to our current protections. 3/

These proposals are entirely based on process rather than substance. A rehash of the flimsy offer Theresa May’s govt made in March. They do nothing to protect or improve workers’ rights, now or in the future. 2/

It seems govt will today announce these proposals, claiming they'll protect workers’ rights. We’ve looked at them and this is our analysis.
 
These are paper promises that fail to mitigate the damage that this deal would do to working people. 1/ https://t.co/8HkdcGsSER

I've seen newspaper reports (based on a cabinet source) that the PM has scrapped the government's commitment to the level playing field. 

Make no mistake: Boris Johnson is coming for our rights at work.

The govt’s proposals would destroy jobs, threaten workers’ rights and undermine the Good Friday Agreement. They’ve failed all of the trade union movement’s key tests. 

The PM must comply with the law and rule out no deal so we can find a real solution to the Brexit crisis.

Working people can't trust Boris Johnson.
 
His Brexit proposals are a sham. He's ready to break the law to force a no deal, which would be disastrous for jobs, livelihoods and our NHS.
 
No amount of bluster can disguise the danger he poses to working families.

Two borders + four years = No Deal. 

It would destabilise the Good Friday Agreement and destroy thousands of jobs on which peace depends. This PM cares nothing for working people in Northern Ireland or anywhere else in the UK.

If a worker was found guilty of gross misconduct they’d have to apologise. Can’t be one law for the PM and another for everyone else. 

Say sorry, stop playing games with other people’s jobs and do what the law requires - rule out no deal.

This judgement couldn't be more damning of the government. They tried to frustrate our democracy - and failed.

Now let MPs get back to work - holding this shabby government and lawless PM to account. And stopping a catastrophic no-deal Brexit.

While the chancellor pats himself on the back, working people are paying the price for the PM’s disastrous mishandling of Brexit. 

The government must take no-deal off the table, seek an extension of Article 50 and deliver a deal that puts jobs, rights and peace first.

At every turn, this prime minister has shown contempt for working people.

Jobs are already being lost, livelihoods are on the line, but as ever the Tory hard right comes first.

MPs must call her out, get no deal off the table and extend Article 50.

Workers at Honda mustn't pay the price for the PM playing to hardliners in her party. Her refusal to take no-deal off the table is putting thousands of jobs in jeapordy. This would be a devasting blow for workers and UK manufacturing.

The prime minister is trying to pull the wool over people’s eyes on workers' rights. We're not buying it. 

The truth is that the government hasn’t offered any substantive change to the Brexit deal. 

My latest 👇 https://t.co/ttsoknXNZN

Solidarity with outsourced @pcs_union members at BEIS, striking today for decent pay. The dept should lead by example, bring contracts back in-house and pay all workers a real living wage. 

Great to join you this morning, and enjoy your brilliant picket playlist!

#HeartUnions https://t.co/Gy10hdZdpm

Yesterday, Theresa May said her party had a proud tradition of protecting workers’ rights.

 The party behind the Trade Union Act and tribunal fees? The government that refuses to ban zero-hours contracts?

We won't be taken in. Our hard-won rights aren't safe in their hands.
Join a union https://t.co/QOSNJOruXb #HeartUnions https://t.co/JrCMDtAuMY
The PM is asking us to entrust our rights at work to a Tory-dominated parliament. That's not a compromise, it's a bad joke. Jobs and rights are still in the firing line. https://t.co/FbFe9kkH7C

Take this with a massive pinch of salt. Only way to guarantee workers' rights is to write protections into the deal and stick by SM and CU rules. Nothing to stop future Tory leaders from ripping up domestic law - exactly what the hardliners aim to do. https://t.co/YmETOlJXWP
Brilliant news! A proud day for @GMB_union and for union organising. Now let's see lots more employers following suit. This is how it's done. https://t.co/pVltQK6XWf
A huge blow for Sunderland and the north east. Painful proof that the government's failure on Brexit is hurting investment in the areas that need it most. https://t.co/CRvATbnHEm

Thanks to all those MPs who recognised that we need a better deal, that protects jobs and rights. Nothing changed last night, and neither has our determination to win a Brexit deal that delivers for working people.
Today MPs can take the prime minister’s threat of no-deal off the table. Here’s our message. https://t.co/Qek2evmGT5

The PM hasn't given us the guarantees we need on jobs or workers' rights. Tweaks aren't enough - we need substantial change to the whole deal.

But even after a catastrophic defeat, her red lines haven't shifted and the threat of no deal hasn't even been taken off the table. https://t.co/AmTlpzXwbw

Important speech from @Keir_Starmer today. We've said all along that sticking by Single Market and Customs Union rules provides the strongest guarantee for jobs and rights. If the PM can't deliver that, then the people need to have the final say.
This crushing defeat shows that Theresa May is out of options. It’s time to give the people the final say, whether through a general election or popular vote.

Though UK governments can and should go higher than EU minimum standards, an EU-wide safety net on rights is a vital protection for UK workers. And the honest truth is the only cast-iron guarantee we can see is cross-border union solidarity and membership of the single market.

Vague assurances aren't good enough. This deal won't stop future governments from watering down our workers' rights. Unions have been clear that we need a binding guarantee that rights in the UK won't fall behind the rest of Europe.

Disappointing, disingenuous intervention from Greg Clark. The government that introduced the Trade Union Act and refused to ban zero-hours contracts now expects working people to take this Brexit deal on trust? https://t.co/bBvjgJCy3Z
The PM has talked a big game on workers' rights all along, but once again the reality falls short. This isn't the binding, long-term guarantee that working people need https://t.co/XCO8Z4hzCJ

It was a privilege to speak at the memorial for Max Levitas yesterday. His spirit lives on today, as we continue that fight against fascism, for a new deal for working people and for our NHS. This film features Max – and a few other famous faces too! https://t.co/e5t9fzMGuy

tweets.text:
Solidarity starts with us.

During times of uncertainty, when change is happening all around, you can rely on your union. 

Join yours today. #BrexitDay https://t.co/oTJ4T7cspt

(1) The PM can expect the shortest honeymoon ever. 

After 9 years of failed austerity the pressure is on to boost living standards and put real investment into our NHS and public services.

And he must deliver a Brexit deal that protects jobs, rights and peace. #UKelection2019

Drug prices, UK vs USA

💉 Insulin
🇬🇧 £16.61 🇺🇸 £215.30
🔺 1300%

🥜 Epipen 300mg
🇬🇧 £52.90 🇺🇸 £523
🔺 1000%

💓 Statin 10mg
🇬🇧 £0.46 🇺🇸 £4.50
🔺 980%

Trump and his Big Pharma cronies want to put up drug prices in our NHS.

As we head for polling day, remember what’s at stake.

It's now clear that our NHS is on the table in any future UK-US trade negotiation. 

We've said it before and we'll say it again: OUR NHS IS NOT FOR SALE

Trade unionists will defend our precious health service to the last breath. #SaveOurNHS https://t.co/0Y6Cv1KAOp

Our history shows that when we work together - we win. That’s what solidarity means. It’s how trade unions have always done things and it’s how we’ll keep winning.

We’re your family at work. Join us today. https://t.co/bddTAnO59S

Suppressing the democratic right to strike is not the way to sort out our railways. No one takes strike action lightly - the Conservatives are trying to stop workers standing up for their jobs and for decent, safe services. https://t.co/KTRZveFwQV

The High Court has ruled against us. Genuinely this is an utter outrage. 110,000 workers vs the establishment.

We will be live shortly. 

Stand strong. We will not be moved #WeRiseAgain 🦁
Solidarity with McDonald's staff striking for fair wages, guaranteed hours and union recognition. Your fight is our fight. #McStrike https://t.co/3hN4JB7uOj

Later this month we will be launching our Working Identities report in Westminster. The event will feature a panel of @FrancesOGrady @MarkJLittlewood and Prof Jacqueline O'Reilly from @SussexUni. Register now on our website:

https://t.co/IGCJDr5KEE https://t.co/lrtbA5BvXC
The UK looks set for a 12 December election after MPs vote to back it following months of deadlock over Brexit https://t.co/4EWHZgj6Ej

I’ve been leaked a recent Dexeu document setting out in black & white how UK plans to diverge from EU on regulations despite Johnson assurances on workers rights etc 

Read it here on @FT 
https://t.co/FsUovcc2Cq https://t.co/I33fZ85l0f

European Union (Withdrawal Agreement) Bill 2019-20
https://t.co/SB4N9nX45F

At any point in this Brexit process, govt could have agreed to an internationally binding legal commitment to maintain existing rights and ensure that rights keep pace. At every stage it’s refused to do so. Why would we trust this sudden change of heart? 6/

And as for relying on the Queen’s Speech as evidence that it supports workers’ rights - all the QS contained was vague, ineffectual commitments and woolly promises. The govt said nothing that would change the game for working people (or challenge big business). 5/

Govt suggesting it will consult on unfair dismissal and TUPE (which would already be weakened the morning after we leave the EU) is meaningless – it’s not a commitment to implementing the changes working people need. 4/

They sit alongside the Brexit deal itself, which doesn’t require that UK rights keep pace, and leaves workers with far less power to enforce rights they do have. These half-baked domestic proposals are no match to our current protections. 3/

These proposals are entirely based on process rather than substance. A rehash of the flimsy offer Theresa May’s govt made in March. They do nothing to protect or improve workers’ rights, now or in the future. 2/

It seems govt will today announce these proposals, claiming they'll protect workers’ rights. We’ve looked at them and this is our analysis.
 
These are paper promises that fail to mitigate the damage that this deal would do to working people. 1/ https://t.co/8HkdcGsSER
New No10 package on workers' rights and environmental protections in the WAB... over to @RuthSmeeth @gareth_snell @SKinnock https://t.co/lKNJoFnWbY

Today MPs face a historic choice. 

Boris Johnson has negotiated a Brexit deal that would hammer the economy, cost jobs and sell workers’ rights down the river. 

We call on every MP to do the right thing for working people and vote against it. https://t.co/AJ7ZBYxp0A

Secretary of State confirms to Brexit Select Committee that previous commitments to level playing field provisions on workers’ rights will no longer apply but appeals to MPs to trust the Govt’s intentions in this area...

WE DID IT!!!

We have absolutely smashed the threshold and YES vote in Royal Mail Group Ballot

75.9% Turnout
97.1% YES

History has been made.

#WeRiseAgain 🦁 https://t.co/s8i4oCgP7s

We offer our support to England’s players, who showed restraint while dealing with such extreme circumstances. 

We commend the team's decisive action in initiating UEFA’s protocol. 

Once again, Southgate’s @England team has shown leadership regarding this issue.

We're a working class family.

Without us there's no NHS, no schools, no transport.

And in tough times we stick together. Because together we can win.

#TUC2019 https://t.co/yrePZwZcLi

#NoDealBrexit means higher fuel prices and a more expensive weekly food shop.

It means destroying good British jobs and taking money away from our NHS.

And it will make us a laughing stock around the world for years.

No to Boris Johnson's disastrous No Deal #Brexit. #TUC2019 https://t.co/bAs515V18l

Multi-billion pound cash boost given to schools   
https://t.co/VUTZ4WYPGb

#OnThisDay in 1969, trans people, lesbians, gay men and bisexuals stood up and resisted police violence at the Stonewall Inn.

50 years later, the fight for LGBT justice and equality continues across the world.

Stonewall never ended. Stonewall is now. #stonewall50 #pride2019 https://t.co/covcThcFU4

This confirms our worst fears - a dodgy trade deal with Trump's America will open our NHS to greedy corporate vultures. 

Trade unions will fight this with all we have. Our NHS is not for sale - not now, not ever. https://t.co/rs8ns28lQW

Last year we showed that people power is stronger than Trump's divisive, hateful politics. 

Let's get together on June 4 to show him he isn't welcome here.

#TogetherAgainstTrump

Details: https://t.co/QSgqyINF7s https://t.co/BhLreO8Mpg

Today's trade union stats show that there's been a rise in the number of employees in trade unions for the second consecutive year. The first time this has happened since 2000.

% of employees in trade unions is also (very slightly) up. https://t.co/dAkU3JwheW

This is devastating news. 

The govt must now do all it can to protect jobs at British Steel and its supply chains. All options must be on the table, including public ownership.

And to every worker worried about their future: your union stands with you. https://t.co/cO4vliMbqQ

Had an amazing ⁦@hopenothate⁩ launch of ⁦@MattHopeNotHate⁩ new book, The Nazi Terrorist. Great speeches by John Bercow, ⁦@FrancesOGrady⁩ ⁦@RuthSmeeth⁩, Tom Jones and ⁦@Tim_Roache⁩. Everyone paid tribute to Robbie Mullen, a real life hero https://t.co/s9ZUop779L

Today we join community groups, human rights organisations and charities to call on all political parties to stand up against unlawful hate speech during the European election campaign. 

These elections must not be abused to sow hatred and division. 

On this, we stand together. https://t.co/yWwxWu2hQJ

‘Keep fighting for your schools and your members, and together we will win a great education for everybody.’
@The_TUC General Secretary @FrancesOGrady delivers a rousing speech to members at #NAHTconf https://t.co/spiLCBmPPR
Good to see TUC General Secretary Frances O’Grady tonight here in Hartlepool. Fantastic speech ahead of Workers Memorial Day tomorrow https://t.co/guIJhxSXZs

Our rights weren't gifted. They were won by workers who refused to accept second best. Happy #InternationalWorkersDay 

#MayDay #MayDay2019 https://t.co/girFOIspCj
Lyra was due to take part in May 4 panel discussion on media freedom post screening of M Colvin film hosted by Amnesty https://t.co/EO9cvyrfVL

What happened in New Zealand is a pure act of terrorism. It's a reminder where Islamophobia and far right ideas can take us.

The union movement stands in solidarity with our New Zealand sisters and brothers and with Muslims here in the UK.

We stand as one against fascism.

There's been a shocking rise in racially motivated attacks. And the far right are rising too. 

To achieve social justice, we've got to challenge the politics of hate and institutional racism. 

We all should feel safe and equal, regardless of race and religion. #Unions4Unity https://t.co/wQlC460s8u

Irish unions secured a huge win for working people this week - an outright ban on zero-hours contracts.

Well done @irishcongress for campaigning for fair pay & job security.

Something that the UK can learn from - if it can be done in Ireland it can be done here.

Vague assurances aren't good enough. This deal won't stop future governments from watering down our workers' rights. Unions have been clear that we need a binding guarantee that rights in the UK won't fall behind the rest of Europe.
